summary: This is Volume II of a videotaped deposition taken on September 8, 2009, in West Palm Beach, Florida, as part of civil litigation against Jeffrey Epstein. The witness, whose name is not provided in this excerpt, is being cross-examined by multiple plaintiff attorneys about his employment as Epstein's house manager, his knowledge of massage therapists, and a personal incident involving theft from Epstein. This document is a transcript of grand jury testimony from a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, likely a butler or house manager. The witness describes his duties related to scheduling and escorting massage therapists to Epstein's residence, payment procedures, and observations about the ages and frequency of visitors. The testimony includes objections from a defense attorney and questioning by a prosecutor. This document is a deposition transcript of a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, likely a butler or house manager. The witness testifies about finding sex toys after massages involving Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, his stressful working conditions, and admits to stealing money from Epstein's briefcase after leaving employment. The deposition includes cross-examination about a police investigation into the theft. This document is a transcript of grand jury testimony where a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein is being questioned about his employment, financial dealings, and specific incidents involving Epstein. The witness discusses taking cash from Epstein, property purchases, a separation agreement, and interactions with investigators. This document is a deposition transcript of a witness (likely Alfredo Rodriguez or a house manager) being questioned by multiple attorneys about his employment at Jeffrey Epstein's El Brillo residence. The witness discusses his duties, interactions with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, the presence of young girls, lists of massage therapists, and his separation agreement with Epstein. The questioning covers his knowledge of various individuals including Alan Dershowitz, Prince Andrew, and others. This document is a deposition transcript of a witness (likely a former house manager) being questioned by attorneys about his employment at Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence from approximately 1992 to 2002. The testimony covers the witness's observations of massage therapists, his relationship with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, the presence of a minor (N.B.), and the discovery of sex toys in the home. This document is a deposition transcript of a witness, identified as Mr. Alessi, being questioned by multiple attorneys (Mr. Critton, Ms. Ezell, Mr. Mermelstein). The questioning focuses on the witness's knowledge of individuals who visited Jeffrey Epstein's home, particularly massage therapists, and the recruitment activities of Ghislaine Maxwell. It also covers the witness's personal interactions with Epstein, Maxwell, and others, and his state of mind regarding the job. This document is a transcript excerpt from a deposition in a civil case related to Jeffrey Epstein. The witness, whose name is not provided in this chunk, is being questioned about their knowledge of Epstein's situation, their feelings about him, and their prior statements regarding a young girl seen at Epstein's residence. The deposition involves multiple attorneys and concludes with the witness waiving the right to read and sign the transcript.

events.title: Witness Begins Part-Time Work for Epstein
events.description: The witness started working part-time for Jeffrey Epstein at his house.

events.title: Witness Begins Full-Time Employment with Epstein
events.description: The witness left all other clients and began working full-time exclusively for Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Deposition of Epstein's House Manager
events.description: Videotaped deposition of Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager is taken in West Palm Beach, Florida, as part of civil litigation.

events.title: Witness Steals Money from Epstein
events.description: The witness admits to taking money from Jeffrey Epstein without permission, leading to a private settlement where Epstein did not involve the police.

events.title: Police Contact Witness Regarding Epstein Investigation
events.description: After Epstein's criminal case became public, the witness found a business card from a Palm Beach police officer at his home, leading him to contact Epstein.

events.title: Witness Meets with Investigator at Carabbas
events.description: After being contacted by police, the witness met with an investigator (name not recalled) at a Carabbas restaurant for about 15 minutes to answer questions about Epstein.

events.title: Witness Leaves Epstein Employment
events.description: The witness left his employment with Jeffrey Epstein in December 2002 due to health issues, stress, and Ghislaine Maxwell's attitude.

events.title: Theft from Epstein's Briefcase
events.description: The witness admits to entering Epstein's home at night on two occasions (once around Labor Day weekend 2003 and once in mid-September 2003) and stealing a total of $6,300 from his briefcase.

events.title: Epstein Reports Burglary to Police
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein reported a burglary to Palm Beach Police, claiming cash was taken from his briefcase and a black Glock handgun was missing from a bookshelf.

events.title: Witness Gives Sworn Statement
events.description: The witness gave a sworn statement to an Assistant State Attorney in 2005, which is marked as Exhibit 2 in the deposition.

events.title: Discovery of Sex Toys After Massages
events.description: The witness testifies to finding sex toys (vibrators/dildos) in a basket in Ghislaine Maxwell's closet and having to clean them up after massages involving Epstein, Maxwell, and others.

events.title: Separation Agreement Signed
events.description: The witness and Jeffrey Epstein signed a separation agreement, which included a confidentiality provision, after the witness left Epstein's employment. The witness received $30,000 and his wife received $20,000.

events.title: First Alleged Cash Incident
events.description: A police report references an incident over Labor Day weekend where the witness allegedly took cash from Jeffrey Epstein's home. The witness acknowledges taking cash twice but disputes the specific dates and a third instance.

events.title: Third Alleged Cash Incident
events.description: A police report references a third alleged incident in early October 2003 where the witness took cash. The witness denies a third visit, stating he only went to Epstein's home twice.

events.title: Business Incorporation
events.description: The witness incorporated a limited liability company (related to 'Properties') through his lawyer Adam Fetterman. He denies any involvement or payment from Epstein for this.

events.title: Witness Separation from Epstein
events.description: The witness left Epstein's employment at the end of December 2002 after discovering people were being interviewed for his job, and negotiated a separation agreement including a year's salary and a van.

events.title: Financial Incident and Repayment
events.description: The witness took money from Epstein in 2003, later repaid $6,310 after Epstein threatened legal action but acknowledged him as his best employee.

events.title: Deposition Testimony
events.description: The witness gives deposition testimony about his employment at Epstein's residence, including observations of young girls and household operations.

events.title: Witness Statement to State Attorney
events.description: The witness gave a statement to the State Attorney's Office in the presence of his attorney, Mr. Murrell.

events.title: Witness Employment at Epstein Residence
events.description: The witness worked as a house manager for Jeffrey Epstein at his Palm Beach home for approximately 11-13 years, ending in December 2002.

events.title: Discovery of Sex Toys
events.description: During the last few months of his employment, the witness found two vibrators (one described as a dildo) in a sink, cleaned them, and returned them to Ghislaine Maxwell's closet.

events.title: Recruitment of Massage Therapists
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell, accompanied by the witness, visited local spas and massage schools to recruit young women to come to Epstein's home to give massages.

events.title: Frequent Massages at Epstein Home
events.description: The witness testifies that Jeffrey Epstein received up to three massages per day 'very often,' and Ghislaine Maxwell received a massage nearly every day.

events.title: Domestic Incident Involving Tony Figueroa
events.description: The witness recounts picking up the massage therapist 'R.' and finding her crying; she told him her boyfriend, Tony Figueroa, had gotten mad and slit furniture and a screen porch with a razor blade or knife.

keyFacts: The witness worked as Jeffrey Epstein's house manager from part-time in 1990 to full-time from January 1, 1991.
The witness admitted to stealing money from Epstein, which was settled privately without police involvement, creating a sense of personal loyalty.
The witness's wife was also employed by Epstein, hired on the witness's recommendation, to handle shopping, errands, and occasional driving for Epstein's mother.
The witness stated he was never instructed to check the identification of massage therapists who came to Epstein's house and was paid $100 per hour.
After Epstein's criminal case became public, the witness was contacted by police and was provided an attorney, Mr. Murrell, by Epstein.
The witness, a former employee, was the primary person letting massage therapists into Epstein's home, escorting them upstairs, and sometimes paying them $100 per session.
Massage therapists (referred to as 'girls' or 'women') typically entered through the kitchen service entrance, and appointments were scheduled in advance.

The witness recalls most therapists being young women, but also mentions some older women and even male therapists. One woman over 60 was rejected by Ghislaine Maxwell, who instructed the witness to pay her and send her away.
During massages for Epstein, the bedroom door would be closed, sessions typically lasted an hour, and sometimes two therapists would arrive simultaneously for massages in different rooms.
The witness was put in contact with an attorney, Mr. Murrell, by an Epstein investigator, but did not know who was paying for the legal services and never received a bill.
A former Epstein employee testified that a basket of sex toys (vibrators/dildos) was kept in Ghislaine Maxwell's closet and had to be cleaned up after massages involving Epstein and Maxwell.
The witness admitted to stealing $6,300 from Jeffrey Epstein's briefcase on two occasions after leaving his employment, entering the home at night when no one was there.
Epstein reported a burglary to police in October 2003, claiming cash and a black Glock handgun were stolen; the witness denied taking the gun.
The witness left Epstein's employment in December 2002 due to health issues, extreme stress, long hours, and Ghislaine Maxwell's negative attitude.
The deposition reveals the witness was contacted by police via a card left at his door, which prompted him to call Epstein out of fear it was about the thefts.
A former employee of Jeffrey Epstein testified about taking cash from Epstein's home on two occasions in 2003, motivated by personal financial trouble with a woman from Brazil.
The witness had a separation agreement with Epstein signed in January 2003, which included a confidentiality clause and payments of $30,000 to him and $20,000 to his wife.
Police reports referenced three specific instances of cash being taken (Labor Day weekend 2003, mid-September 2003, and October 4/5, 2003), but the witness insisted he only went to the house twice.
The witness detailed multiple property purchases in Palm Beach County between 1983 and 2004, claiming Epstein only contributed $20,000 toward one apartment purchase in 1997.
The witness incorporated a business in August 2003 through his lawyer Adam Fetterman and vehemently denied Epstein had any involvement in or paid for this business entity.
The witness maintained lists of massage therapists with names and phone numbers that were kept in multiple locations around Epstein's properties and were updated regularly.
The witness observed "one or two young ones in the last year" of his employment, specifically identifying individuals referred to as V.R. and N.B., with N.B. estimated to be 16-17 years old.
The witness described a change in household dynamics when Ghislaine Maxwell arrived, stating she made life difficult for staff and that Epstein became less interactive.
The witness confirmed that Alan Dershowitz and Prince Andrew visited Epstein's house but denied seeing any inappropriate behavior or nudity during their visits.
The witness entered into a separation agreement with Epstein in late 2002 that included a confidentiality provision, though he claimed not to understand its purpose.
The witness testified that over 11 years, he saw possibly 100-200 different massage therapists (men and women) coming to Epstein's home, but he believed all the women were 18 or older.
The witness stated the only female he knew to be under 18 visiting the house was N.B., a 16-17 year old he would pick up from high school, who visited with her mother and was mentored by Epstein.
The witness claimed he never saw any massage therapist appear distraught, scared, upset, or injured after giving Epstein a massage.
The witness described finding two vibrators (one a dildo) in a sink during the last months of his employment, which he cleaned and returned to Ghislaine Maxwell's closet.
The witness's relationship with Epstein was described as 'good,' while his relationship with Maxwell was not as good; he disagreed with her desire to run the house 'as a royal house.'
The witness, a former employee, states Ghislaine Maxwell actively recruited massage therapists for Jeffrey Epstein by visiting spas and massage schools in the area from Jupiter to Boca Raton.
The witness testifies that Jeffrey Epstein received up to three massages per day, and this happened 'very often.'
The witness clarifies that a young girl he knew was underage (N.B.) was not a massage therapist but came to the house as a friend, while another young woman (V.) was a massage therapist.
The witness describes a contentious working relationship with Ghislaine Maxwell, characterizing her as 'rotten spoiled' and detailing her demanding shopping habits and blame-shifting.
The witness recounts an incident where massage therapist 'R.' reported her boyfriend, Tony Figueroa, caused significant property damage during a domestic argument.
The witness felt bad for Jeffrey Epstein due to the negative publicity he received, citing a ten-year friendship and Epstein's generosity.
The witness's prior statement from November 21, 2005, referenced a young girl at Epstein's residence, noting 'she looked young' but that it was 'not my job' to ask her age.
During clarification, the witness stated the girl in question did not look like a 16-year-old to them.
The witness confirmed they had only spoken to their wife and Mr. Critton about the civil cases or their deposition testimony.
The deposition concluded with the witness waiving their right to read and sign the typed transcript.
